ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned about organic chemistry
I learned about acids/bases, basic organic reaction mechanisms, and E2/Sn2/E1/Sn1 mechanisms.

I gained a foundational understanding or organic chemistry concepts that will serve me well as I take more advanced courses like biochemistry. Professor Herzon also did a great job of bribing in relevant scientific literature to remind his students about the broader importance of organic chemistry beyond memorization of nomenclature and reaction pathways.
A solid understanding of basic organic chemistry
Learned about several chemical reactions (including mechanisms) with an emphasis on understanding the reasoning behind each concept.
Applied general chemistry basics and learned chemistry of carbon compounds
Introduction and understanding of organic chemistry reaction mechanisms
Organic chemistry knowledge
I learned organic chemistry and found that following along in the book really helps.
I learned the basics of organic chemistry, like hyperconjugation, resonance, etc, and was able to apply these principles to various reactions.

I learned how to draw mechanisms for different types of reactions (free radicals, oxyboration, H-X additions to alkenes, etc.). We also learned about resonance structures, orbital hybridization, SN1/SN2/E1/E2 reactions, stereochemistry, and more.
Drawing structures
I learned the fundamentals of organic chemistry
In this course, I learned the fundamentals of organic chemistry.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the lectures were always very organized and I really enjoyed the material of the course. Also, the exams were very doable, especially with the accommodations that Prof. Herzon gave us. I think there really wasn't much to be improved other than getting more feedback on our quizzes/exams.
Strengths - Professor Herzon is one of the best professors I have had at Yale and did a wonderful job accommodating student needs in the midst of a stressful and unusual virtual semester.

Strenghts: Prof. Herzon is concerned with making students understand the material in an intuitive way

Weakness: clearer feedback on the psets would have been helpful
It would be helpful if this class was actually meant to help students learn the material rather than being a weed-out class.
Weaknesses: Some of the exam/PSET questions were a bit too different (and thus difficult) from the lecture material.

Strengths - weekly PSET/quizzes helped for practice purpose 
Weakness - execution of course content
There is a lot of information that is crammed into one semester.
Great prof
The strengths of the course is how well the professor could explain the hard material.

The strengths were that the lecture notes were so well organized and well taught. I was able to follow along and look back at my notes and know what to study. I also really liked having the weekly group quizzes because they forced me to try to grasp the material. However, I feel like the quizzes were a lot more difficult than the material we learned in class so a lot of times we were no sure if we were doing the work correctly.

The group quizzes on Friday could have been better facilitated. The material on these quizzes also seemed harder/different from what we learned in class sometimes and required time beyond what was given on Fridays and going to office hours. The class overall was very well taught and I appreciated the live drawings of all of the reactions.

The professor does a great job of explaining concepts in a way that's clear, comprehensive, and easy to understand. While the concepts themselves were difficult, the problem sets and Sapling questions as well as the teaching staff (professor and TAs) helped me get a better grasp of organic chemistry and not feel so intimidated by the large amount of content. I wish we could've had time to learn the later topics of the book (thiols, ethers, etc.), but I'm happy with what I was able to learn. A big weakness of the course was the difficulty of the group problem sets. For a lot of them, we had to wait for a TA to enter the breakout room and give us hints on how to solve the problems, which misses the point of assigning us problems to do in the first place. It would've been so much easier if the problem sets related more directly to the things we learned in lectures.
Group work- people do more wok than others.

The instructor was pretty good at teaching what he taught. The only weakness of the course was that office hours were held directly after class which I could not attend due to overlap with other classes.

Strengths: the quality of content presented by Prof. Herzon as well as the flexibility and strong email communications of the TFs and Prof. Herzon. Another strength was transparency in communication, from office hours to exam changes.

One weakness was quality of notes - it was definitely hard to decode tablet handwriting -- just a consequence of virtual classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the format of having live virtual (but recorded) lectures was really helpful because we could go back to any lecture and watch it if we were confused about something. But, I think the quizzes on Fridays weren't great on Zoom because breakout rooms aren't always productive.

The whiteboard used on Zoom and recording of lectures really helped to facilitate student learning (who ch was remarkable, considering that organic chemistry is such a visual subject that often requires the building of 3D models).

Recording lectures was super helpful, Friday problem-solving sessions were good but often Prof. Herzon would have to review the content for Friday's recorded lecture on Monday, which made it a little repetitive.
The take-home exams were very accomodating for students in different time zones!
Most of the visual, hands-on learning aspects of organic chem
Nothinng
I liked how the professor recorded all lectures so if we missed that day or needed to review, we could watch it again.
I liked the way lectures and notes were organized.

The 2 days live, one day recorded model was good, but sometimes it lead to me missing the next Monday's lecture and falling behind for the week because I had not watched the previous Friday's lecture yet. I was not the biggest fan of the Friday quizzes. but I do think it helped us review topics from the week.

Zoom made watching lectures much more accessible to me. In addition to the recorded lectures allowing me to learn at my own pace, I was able to better absorb the material when the teaching staff shared their screens versus if I had to learn from them writing on chalkboards. However, being in breakout rooms during discussion sections or Friday group work meant having to wait a long time to get a TA to help, which wasn't fun.
Live recorded lectures
More office hours

I really enjoyed the ability to rewatch lectures and office hours -- that was particularly important especially when you couldn't make the times due to other classes.

I did not really enjoy the group quizzes. My first group was great, but the second group it was essentially me going to office hours everytime and writing the psets by myself.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had to take this class, but it was still quite interesting. Professor Herzon's lectures were pretty well-organized. He tried to make concepts as clear and organized as possible.

Yes! Before taking this course I thought that organic chemistry would be an extremely difficult class, but I think Prof. Herzon did such a great job making the material easy to understand. He is also such a kind person and one of the best lecturers I've had at Yale. Even if you hated general chemistry, take this class because it'll make you love chemistry!
I would definitely recommend taking organic chemistry with Professor Herzon if you have to take this course for major or pre-medical requirements.
For a requirement or if you are interested in organic chemistry

Yes, if a pre-med student necessary for med school. 
Otherwise, chemistry-lovers would enjoy this course a lot
Yes
Yes because youre going to need it for premed and other stem majors.

If you are taking this class, it is probably for your major or pre-med, so for that reason I do recommend this course. Taking it with Professor Herzon is probably your best bet because he makes the topics easier to learn.

I would recommend this course as long as you have Seth Herzon as the professor. He explains the concepts in a way that's easy to understand, and I don't think I would have found the same amount of success with organic chemistry if I was taught by anyone else.
Needed for med school
Yes, I would recommend taking orgo off sequence if it has a better professor than the on sequence class.
Yes! Prof. Herzon is super clear and my TF was great. Definitely a difficult class to take online, but the ability to rewatch lectures was insanely helpful.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly collaborative group quizzes really helped reinforce the material in a stress free environment.

M,W: in-person lecture
F: recorded lecture, in-person group quiz
There were live virtual lectures every M/W and recorded lectures for F.
Recorded lectures on Friday, discussion
live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section
Some recorded lectures at end of week
Live lectures that were also recorded plus weekly live virtual discussion section.
Live virtual review sessions, discussion sections.
recorded lecture
Recorded Friday lectures
The professor recorded all lectures and prerecorded Friday lectures so we could do quizzes instead. We had to watch Friday lectures on our own time.
Break out groups/discussion sections too
live virtual lecture that was also recorded

We had live lectures on Mondays and Wednesdays, and then on Fridays we had a flipped classroom setting where we split up into groups and work on a problem set. On Thursdays, we would be given a recorded lecture that we were expected to watch by the next Monday (at the latest).
live virtual lecture
There was live, recorded lecture on Mondays and Wednesdays and on Fridays, we were placed in small groups to work together on the weekly problem sets.
Virtual recorded lectures with a virtual group quiz for one session each week.
